section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce community helpers, engage children with dance, and introduce vocabulary (weigh, count) .
Begin Story Time by asking, What helpers work in our community?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing measurement tools in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Know the purpose of common measuring tools (e.g., ruler, scale, measuring cup/spoon).

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to find cards with matching measurement tools.
Guide children to identify the tool on each card and its use.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What helpers are in this book?
Pretend you are at the store. What helpers are there?
How many Connecting Cubes are you using? Count them carefully.
A firefighter is a community helper. Tell a story about a firefighter.
Draw a picture of a community helper.
The word helper starts with the letter H. Can you trace that letter?
What are you making? Do any community helpers work in this building?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder demonstrate empathy and introduce vocabulary (help, materials) .
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builders to Whose Hands are These?
Read closely to talk about participating in the class community and taking care of materials.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.
Know the purpose of common measuring tools (e.g., ruler, scale, measuring cup/spoon).
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—describing number and length of sides and number of angles.
Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to compare the height, length, or weight of two objects by observation.
Challenge children to use the words taller, longer, or heavier to describe the comparison.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Does anyone in this book have a job? Are they a community helper?
What are you cooking? How did you measure the ingredients?
What measuring tools do you see?
Describe a time that you met a community helper.
What are you making? Why did you choose those materials?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word measure? Can you trace the letter that makes that sound?
Make a tower. Which is taller: you or the tower? How do you know?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to learn about measurement, engage children with music, and introduce vocabulary (cook, measure).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Whose Hands are These? and asking the guiding question, What do community helpers measure?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and a focus on measurement.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.
Know the purpose of common measuring tools (e.g., ruler, scale, measuring cup/spoon).
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to create a building using Pattern Blocks.
Guide children to name shapes and discuss that the position of a shape does not matter.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Are any measuring tools used in this book?
Pretend you are at a construction site. What can you measure here?
Use Connecting Cubes to measure how long or tall three things are.
Make a drawing of or write about a building.
What will you make today? Can you describe it?
Trace the letter T. What sound does it make?
Build a hospital or doctor’s office. What helpers work here? How do they help people?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Whose Hands Are These? by Miranda Paul, illustrated by Luciana Navarro Powell. Text copyright © 2016 by Miranda Paul. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Luciana Navarro Powell. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Millbrook Press, a division of Lerner Publishing Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Super Jobs

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to revisit the concept question, talk about local community helpers, and introduce vocabulary (doctor, firefighter) .
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Super Jobs and Whose Hands are These?
Read closely to connect to this week’s concept question, Who are the people who help in our community?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name,and describe common two dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle using words related to number and length of sides and number of angles.
Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes.
Know the purpose of common measuring tools (e.g.,ruler, scale, measuring cup/spoon.)
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to act as bakers, creating a “cake” with “layers” of Pattern Blocks arranged by shape.
Guide children to name shapes and discuss that the position of a shape does not matter.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Does the person in this book help others? How?
Pretend to work in a store. Are the things you sell heavy or light? Big or small?
Can you find different-sized shapes in the classroom?
How does your teacher help you?
Make a hat for community helpers to help them do their jobs.
Use letters to make your name.
How can you take care of the materials in this center?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Whose Hands Are These? by Miranda Paul, illustrated by Luciana Navarro Powell. Text copyright © 2016 by Miranda Paul. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Luciana Navarro Powell. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Millbrook Press, a division of Lerner Publishing Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to practice counting, engage children with a song, and introduce new vocabulary (farmer, news reporter).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book Whose Hands are These? and asking, How do the people in our community help us?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.
Know the purpose of common measuring tools (e.g., ruler, scale, measuring cup/spoon.)
Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What kind of community helper would you like to be?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How did the character in this book feel? Can you imagine feeling like that?
Pretend to be a community helper. Why did you choose that one?
Measure how many Connecting Cubes long your favorite book is.
Which classroom job is your favorite? Write about it!
Why is it so important to take care of the materials in this station?
Can you make your first name using letters that you see here?
Make two towers. Which one is taller? How could you make the smaller tower larger than the tall tower?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use words to rote count from 1 to 30.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Participate in classroom music activities including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Name common shapes.
Slide, flip, and turn shapes to demonstrate that the shapes remain the same.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Assume various roles and responsibilities as part of a classroom community.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Name common shapes.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Participate in classroom music activities including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Slide, flip, and turn shapes to demonstrate that the shapes remain the same.
Name common shapes.
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Assume various roles and responsibilities as part of a classroom community.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Use words to rote count from 1 to 30.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Assume various roles and responsibilities as part of a classroom community.
Participate in classroom music activities including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
